contact.institution: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis JEL423 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Batrachochytrium is a pathogen of amphibians implicated as a primary causative agent of amphibian declines. This recently emerging pathogen was identified in 1998 as the cause of amphibian deaths in Australia and Central America. More recently, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has been implicated in population declines of frog species in North America, South America, Europe and Africa. This fungus invades the top layers of skin cells and causes thickening of the keratinized layer. As a representative of the Chytridiomycota (chytrids), the sequence of B. dendrobatidis is the first in this largely uncharacterized phylum of fungi.
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: We produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7.4X assembly was made public in September of 2006, and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future 2006 releases.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Broad Institute sequenced the diploid Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis strain JEL423 genome at 7.4X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. The current assembly (Assembly 1) consists of 348 nuclear genome contigs in 69 supercontigs, and 3 mitochondrial genome contigs in 1 supercontig. The genome assembly will undergo automated annotation.

contact.name: Bruce Birren
contact.institution: Whitehead Institute Center for Genome Research

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Neurospora crassa OR74A Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: The approximately 40-megabase genome encodes about 10,000 protein-coding genes—more than twice as many as in the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe and only about 25% fewer than in the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster
dataSourceAttribution.protocol:
The genome sequence was assembled from deep whole-genome shotgun (WGS) coverage obtained by paired-end sequencing from a variety of clone types.
Sequencing methods for all clone types are described at http://www-genome.wi.mit.edu/. The sequence was assembled using Arachne
dataSourceAttribution.description: N crassa draft genome was sequenced, annotated and reported by the Broad Institute in collaboration with the Neurospora research community.

contact.name: Sébastien Duplessis
contact.institution: Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique/Nancy Université

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici CRL75367003 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: The pathogenic fungus Puccinia graminis causes stem rust in small cereal crops such as wheat, oat, rye, and barley. Stem rust, also referred to as black rust or black stem rust, is among the most destructive diseases of cereal crops and has resulted in enormous economic and yield losses. Puccinia graminis has a complex life cycle that includes five spore stages and two very different hosts, namely, a grass for the primary host and, most commonly, barberry as the alternate host. Puccinia graminis has a number of "special forms", or forma speciales (f. sp.), which differ in their primary host specificities.
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: We produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7X assembly was made public in January of 2007, and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future releases.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici strain CRL 75-36-700-3 genome sequence submitted to INSD by the Broad Institute.

contact.institution: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Histoplasma capsulatum NAm1 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: For Histoplasma capsulatum class NAmI strain WU24, we produced whole genome shotgun sequence from two plasmid libraries (4kb and 10kb inserts) and a Fosmid library. The resulting 7X assembly was made public in September 2005, and the results of automated genome annotation was made public May, 2006.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Ajellomyces capsulatus reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by the NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Ajellomyces capsulatus strain NAm1 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad Institute.

contact.institution: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Histoplasma capsulatum G186AR Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Histoplasma capsulatum is the most common cause of fungal respiratory infections (histoplasmosis) in the world. While most infections are mild, 10% of cases result in life-threatening complications such as inflammation of the pericardium and fibrosis of major blood vessels (Durkin, Kohler et al. 2001). In addition, some African H. capsulatum isolates cause a distinct disease, African histoplasmosis, that is characterized by cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions in the bone (Jones and Goodwin., 1981). Once infected, a latent infection may be reactivated. Histoplasma poses a particular threat to the elderly and to immunocompromised patients (Rachid, Rezende et al. 2003).
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: The Latin American Histoplasma capsulatum class H81 strain G186AR was assembled from sequence reads produced by both the Broad Institute and the Washington University School of Medicine. Sequences were obtained from 454 pOT library beads and fosmid libraries containing 3.1kb, 4.1kb, 5.7 kb, and 39kb inserts. The resulting 10X assembly was made public in May 2008 and the results of automated genome annotation will be made public in future releases.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Washington University School of Medicine (WashU), in collaboration with the Broad Institute and the University of California at San Francisco, sequenced the Histoplasma capsulatum strain G186AR genome at 6X coverage using whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing. Together with the 4X coverage provided by Broad Institute, the team built a high quality assembly that is currently being annotated.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cryptococcus gattii R265 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: C. gattii was initially classified as a variety of C. neoformans but has recently been recognized as a separate species. These pathogens are responsible for infections in immunocompromised and immunocompetent hosts.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Cryptococcus gattii sequence was assembled by Kronstad Lab at at the University of British Columbia.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Neurospora tetrasperma FGSC 2508 mat A Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: N. tetrasperma is the only Neurospora species that employs a mating strategy that combines selfing with occasional outbreeding using a novel genetic system (pseudohomothallism) and provides a model for studying both the genomic and evolutionary consequences of asexuality and inbreeding.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Neurospora tetrasperma was sequenced and annotated at the JGI and the project has been submitted to Genbank under accession number AFBT00000000

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Coprinopsis cinerea Ok7h130 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Coprinopsis cinerea, also known as Coprinus cinereus, is a multicellular basidiomycete that undergoes a complete sexual cycle, including typical mushroom formation. Extensive genetic and molecular analyses of this organism can be performed due to its easy cultivation on defined minimal media, making it a great model for studying development and regulation in multicellular organisms. The Coprinopsis cinerea genome is estimated at 37.5 Mb, organized in 13 chromosomes. Over 100 markers involved in mating type, hyphal growth, fruit body morphogenesis, and DNA repair have been assigned to 10 linkage groups. RFLP and RAPD markers are widely used.
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: Broad produced whole genome shotgun sequence from 4kb & 10kb plasmids and 40kb Fosmids.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Coprinopsis cinerea reference sequence (RefSeq) genome is provided by NCBI. It is a curated copy of the Coprinopsis cinerea strain okayama 7#130 genome sequence submitted to GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ by the Broad institute. The Coprinopsis genome project is a partnership between the Broad Institute and the Coprinopsis research community. Genomic DNA for the genome project was provided by Patricia Pukkila at University of North Carolina.

contact.name: Li-Jun Ma
contact.institution: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Rhizopus oryzae 99880 Sequence and Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Rhizopus oryzae is a widely dispersed fungus that can cause fatal infections in people with suppressed immune systems, especially diabetics or organ transplant recipients. Antibiotic therapy alone is rarely curative, particularly in patients with disseminated infection. We sequenced the genome of a pathogenic R. oryzae strain and found evidence that the entire genome had been duplicated at some point in its evolution and retained two copies of three extremely sophisticated systems involved in energy generation and utilization. The ancient whole-genome duplication, together with recent gene duplications, has led to the expansion of gene families related to pathogen virulence, fungal-specific cell wall synthesis, and signal transduction, which may contribute to the aggressive and frequently life-threatening growth of this organism. We also identified cell wall synthesis enzymes, essential for fungal cell integrity but absent in mammals, which may present potential targets for developing novel diagnostic and therapeutic treatments. R. oryzae represents the first sequenced fungus from the early lineages of the fungal phylogenetic tree, and thus the genome sequence sheds light on the evolution of the entire fungal kingdom.
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: The genome sequence was assembled from 454 Whole Genome Shotgun methods using fragment and paired-end reads to iteratively build the supercontigs. The annotation was performed using automated methods.
dataSourceAttribution.description: The Rhizopus oryzae sequence project is part of the Fungal Genome Initiative at the Broad Institute of Harvard and MIT. The goal of this project is to release 10X sequence coverage for Rhizopus oryzae strain 99-880 (it also have been called RA 99-880). The strain was isolated in 1999 from a brain abscess of a diabetic patient who developed fatal rhinocerebral mucormycosis.

dataSourceAttribution.description: Phytophthora capsici is a highly dynamic and destructive pathogen of vegetables. It attacks all cucurbits, pepper, tomato and eggplant, and, more recently, snap and lima beans. Genome sequences were assembled and annotated at the JGI.

dataSourceAttribution.description: Pythium ultimum is a ubiquitous oomycete plant pathogen responsible for a variety of diseases on a broad range of crop and ornamental species. Genome sequences were annotated at Michigan State University.Please cite Levesque et al. Genome Biol. 2010;11:R73.

contact.institution: Washington University School of Medicine, St. Louis

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: C.neoformans - Transcriptome analysis of ada2Δ, nrg1Δ and cir1Δ and KN99Α
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Identify Cryptococcus neoformans genes based on Transcriptome analysis of ada2&Delta, nrg1&Delta and cir1&Delta and KN99&Alpha wildtype cells in capsule inducing and non-inducing conditions.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Ccin Hyphal Growth Time Series Rna Seq Expression Data
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Identify Coprinopsis cinerea genes based on fold change expression difference between a "comparison" and a "reference" sample.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing hyphal sections from 2 time points (9 days and 15 days) of hyphal growth on solid media for Coprinopsis cinerea. This experiment is intended to compare genes expressed on the hyphal edge and in the colony.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Rory Hyphal Growth Time Series Rna Seq Expression Data
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Identify Rhizopus oryzae genes based on fold change expression difference between a "comparison" and a "reference" sample.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing 3 time points (3hrs, 5hrs, and 20hrs) of hyphal growth on solid media for Rhizopus oryzae. The 3 hrs is the youngest tissue and from the hyphal tip while the 5 and 20 represent more interior to the colony and more mature tissue.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cimm Comparative Transcriptomics Rna Seq Expression Data
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases of Coccidiodes immitis and C. posadasii. Of the 9,910 total predicted genes in Coccidioides, 1,298 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the saprobic phase of both C. immitis and C. posadasii and 1,880 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the parasitic phase of both species
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: Illumina mRNA sequencing libraries for saprobic-phase hyphae and parasitic-phase spherules in vitro for C. immitis isolate RS and C. posadasii isolate C735 were prepared in biological triplicate
dataSourceAttribution.description: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases. The results highlighted a number of genes that may be crucial to dimorphic phase-switching and virulence in Coccidioides.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Cpos Comparative Transcriptomics Rna Seq Expression Data
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases of Coccidiodes immitis and C. posadasii. Of the 9,910 total predicted genes in Coccidioides, 1,298 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the saprobic phase of both C. immitis and C. posadasii and 1,880 genes were observed to be up-regulated in the parasitic phase of both species
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: Illumina mRNA sequencing libraries for saprobic-phase hyphae and parasitic-phase spherules in vitro for C. immitis isolate RS and C. posadasii isolate C735 were prepared in biological triplicate
dataSourceAttribution.description: Comparative transcriptomics were used to identify gene expression differences between the saprobic and parasitic growth phases. The results highlighted a number of genes that may be crucial to dimorphic phase-switching and virulence in Coccidioides.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Neurospora crassa OR74A Expression Data
dataSourceAttribution.summary: This study compared gene expression from 3 different time points in hyphal growth by cutting 1 cm strip of tissue from the hyphal tip (3hrs old), several cm back (5hrs old) and further back in the colony (20hrs old) in Neurospora crassa OR74A growing on VM media
dataSourceAttribution.description: Unpublished data from Stajich lab at UC Riverside representing 3 time points (3hrs, 5hr, and 20hrs) of hyphal growth on solid media for Neurospora crassa.

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: N crassa population genomics
dataSourceAttribution.summary: This study uses a "reverse-ecology" population genomic approach to identify ecologically relevant phenotypes in organisms that are difficult to study in nature.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Neurospora crasss data from Christopher Ellison et al. from Taylor Lab at at UC Berkeley on whole-transcriptome sequencing of 48 individuals to identify SNPs

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: RNA-Seq Expression - C albicans Comprehensive Annotation
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Massively parallel high-throughput sequencing of cDNA was used to generate a high-resolution map of the C. albicans transcriptome under several different environmental conditions. The regions that are transcribed under the different conditions have been quantitatively determined and 635 novel transcriptionally active regions (TARs) and numerous novel introns have bben identified
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: Data has been generated for C. albicans (strain SC5314) grown under a total of nine different in vitro conditions. Using our data set of about 177 million mapped reads, we have significantly refined the primary annotations of the C. albicans genome by determining the position of transcripts in the genomes, including 602 newly identified transcripts for strain SC5314, and by identifying 41 new introns.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Candida albicans data from Michael Snyder et al. from Synder Lab at Stanford University on Comprehensive Annotation of the transcriptome of the human fugal pathogen Candida albicans using RNA-Seq

contact.name: Marc Buhler
contact.address: Friedrich Miescher Institute for Biomedical Research

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: RNA-Seq Expression - S pombe Dicer Protein
dataSourceAttribution.summary: Dicer proteins function in RNA interference (RNAi) pathways by generating small RNAs (sRNAs). The solution structure of the C-terminal domain of Schizosaccharomyces pombe Dicer (Dcr1) is reported here. The C-terminal domain of Dcr1 constitutes a novel regulatory module that might represent a potential target for therapeutic intervention with fungal diseases.
dataSourceAttribution.protocol: Small RNA libraries from total RNA isolations of wild-type, dcr1Delta, dcr1SHSS, and dcr1Deltaloop2 cells and subjected to high-throughput sequencing.
dataSourceAttribution.description: Schizosaccharomyces pombe data from Pierre Barraud, Marc Buhler et al. from ETH Zurich and FMI Basel on nuclear retention of fission yeast Dicer

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Microarray Expression - Expression profiling of saccharomyces cerevisiae s288c
dataSourceAttribution.summary: The following experiments from Spellman et. al. : (1) Pheromone synchronization time course, (2) Size-based synchronization time course (elutriation), (3) Cdc15-based synchronization time course, (4) Transcriptional response to the cyclins Cln3p and Clb2p. The following experiment is from Cho et. al. Cdc28-based synchronization time course
dataSourceAttribution.description: Saccharomyces cerevisiae cell cycle regulation microarray data

dataSourceAttribution.displayName: P. sojae expression during infection

dataSourceAttribution.description: This study has 2 experimental replicates and each one has 4 biological replicates. The first replicate is from P. sojae mycelial tissue sample grown in media and the second replicate is from Soybean hypocotyls infected with P. sojae 3 dpi.
